comments.commentBody: Maybe it's because your colleague has written about psychological barriers, but what you describe here reminds me a little of the Milgram experiment at Yale, with its subjects acquiescing in delivering (what they thought were) painful shocks to others, as instructed by someone in authority.  I don't think there was even a morality tale to try to justify it and foster a feeling of righteousness.

"...you have been correct at every juncture, and you are correct tonight, we have yet to see the worst of it."

It's good to see that you've come around to seeing the flawed logic in the Mitt / Ryan budget proposals, Mr. Barrett, since, as I'm sure you know, and Mr. Krugman has certainly sermonized on the subject of their austerity budget, Mitt's & Ryan's budget amounts to a uniquely Republican Party approach to austerity.

Counting on another vote for Obama is welcome whatever quarter it comes from, "born again" to Barack's cause or otherwise.

Yes, the Germans have succeeded in dominating Europe, and once again seem to be hell bent on destroying all that they have conquered.

The biggest problem is that most Europeans have limited sight horizons. They think of themselves as Germans, French, Greek, etc. and distantly, almost disparagingly, as a member of the EU.

This is, literally, a foreign concept in most of America. We would never consider punishing an individual state because of a poor decision by its governor. Well, maybe Texas. But we are one nation with the rest.

If Europe is ever to succeed, they will need to develop a sense of national pride in the EU, thus giving up a lot of their "patriotism" to their home country.
Do you agree that "solutions" offered in the US are much the same, just slightly different because of our political structure?

The events in the EU this week Professor become more bizarre by the hour. Spain and Greece are in the headlines, and you described the events in Spain perfectly. The Italian economy is on the edge, having enjoyed a period outside the focus of public scrutiny until now. Fiat is in severe difficulty and has appealed to the Italian Government for more subsidies and they have closed down their last steel mill. We are moving from a grim period toward a potential descent to catastrophe. And the Germans must still have it their way since they are the biggest dogs in the EU.

When some years ago you began to write on the austerity fascination gripping the EU I must admit I was skeptical at first. I follow it on a daily basis and must complement you; you have been correct at every juncture, and you are correct tonight, we have yet to see the worst of it.

The Germans have promoted the acquisition of commercial and formerly privately held bank investment, debt, totally worthless paper, by the governments of the constituent states concerned thereby, since you coined the phrase, socializing the debt. That is making out of country private investment bad debt the responsibility of that nation so that the original investors, including the German government, get paid. That is an austerity level never before experienced. The Irish government announced there was nothing more to do but pay. The Germans have succeeded , the did not in 1870, 1914, and 1939; they now own Europe on the cheap.

Although many people would agree with your comment based on what has been the "status quo" for too many years, to say "why bother" seems quite ignorant. There is suffering on both sides, and to say that refraining from coming to a solution is an option allows for a continuously harmful situation.

However, Mark - I have to say that your analysis is a common and misinformed analysis of the situation. The Israeli-Palestinian conflict can not be summarized as a situation about "taking from the weaker." It is much more complicated than that. Both sides have already seen rude awakenings to do previous circumstances of the conflict in history, now however is the time to continue to advocate for a solution. Saying that this is all Israel's fault is not only incorrect, but it does not serve any purpose. In fact, both sides are to be blamed for various aspects of the conflict.

Finger pointing is not the solution, but most importantly in response to the original post - neither is the status quo.

People that think the situation will remain as it is, with Israel continuing to appropriate land and keeping the Palestinians in ghettos, have their heads in the sand.   Most of the terror that the West has endured, is because of it's support for Israel. The war in Iraq was fought at the instigation of Zionist neo-cons with family ties in Israel.   Israel has lost its enablers one by one in the Middle East over the past 30 years (Iran, Turkey, Egypt, Lebanon).   Most of the world's nations have recognized Palestine within 1967 borders.  The tide is shifting.  When Netanyahu came to power on a platform of subverting the Oslo Accords, Israel made a decision to go it alone.   They decided they didn't need an agreement.  That probably doomed a two-state solution and doomed Israelis to an eventual one-state solution dictated by its neighbors.  The U.S. is best served by staying out because Turkey and Egypt are more important to us than Israel.

@ Michael: and Israel got the best peace plan it was ever likely to get in the shape of the Arab Peace Plan and blew it, beacuse it di not want to give up on the dream of owning the West Bank too.

The Wall is not stopping Palestinians from blowing up Israeli school buses. There are many holes in that wall. (There are, at a conservative estimate, about 50,000 ILLEGAL West Bank workers in Israel at any time: a lot of them use those holes). What is stopping Israeli buses from being blown up is that the Palestinian Authority decided to put its weight behind stopping the bombers, ever since about 2005-6.

The problem remaining unresolved is definitely an option - one pursued by both the Zionists and the Palestinians since the 1920s.  The Palestinians Authority is hardly going to risk it suzerainty of the West Bank by telling its people that they are never going back to their lands in Israel.  The Israeli government is hardly going to have a showdown with the religious zealots over the settlements.  Why bother there is no real will on either side - and the United States certainly isn't pressing - and plenty of reasons to leave the situation in the limbo its been in for 90 years.
What is your reference for your assertion there are more home invasions and assualts in UK than in USA

@Brent: The murder rate among the Japanese is actually higher than the murder rate by Japanese-born Americans, despite the latter's ability to get guns. If you care only about the rate of gun-crimes specifically, you can reduce those by radically reducing the penalties for the same crimes when committed without using guns -- you just have to give criminals an incentive.

Gun manufacturing will become increasingly easy as computer-controlled lathes come down in price. Artisans in villages of Pakistan and the Philippines are already able to make quite functional copies of modern arms.

Yes, the assault rate in the UK is a little over twice that of the US. But the rate of murder by firearms in the US is more than 135 times the rate in the UK. And our suicide rate is nearly twice theirs for most age groups (and higher in the rest).
http://www.nationmaster.com/graph/cri_tot_cri-crime-total-crimes

I find it hard to understand why anyone of intelligence would expect a ban on firearms (or any major restriction) to be of greater influence than the nationwide ban on marijuana. There are enough firearms in circulation that there would never be a shortage on the underground market. On the off chance that there was a shortage, a competent machinist could build one from raw materials in a week. As criminal tools, firearms are quite durable. Buying one, even at black market prices, would ensure a criminal of a good living, especially in a disarmed populace.

An intelligent person would make a cost-benefit analysis and see that firearms are used far more often to halt crimes than to carry them out, 98% of the time without a shot being fired. Criminals don't like the idea of armed citizens. They would prefer an environment like the UK where they are the only ones armed. That's why home invasions and assaults are so much more common there than in the US, where the miscreants never know when they are likely to run up against a citizen ready to defend himself.
And in addition to your point that the same conditions are affecting the adult family members, they also were once children, too.

This is a typical example of the slippery slope fallacy habitually practiced by members of the gun lobby.  You are arguing that the most extreme possible consequence of restricting gun ownership will actually happen, and end with scare tactics.  First, we know from historical experience that gun control does not have to lead to the consequences you outline, as gun control was widely practiced throughout most of the 20th century.  Only in recent times have we seen an extreme loosening of gun laws, strongly correlated with an increasing brutal series of mass murders. You are buying into the myth of an unregulated past and an ever-more regulated present. This is pure myth; get this through your head: regulations have loosened to an absurd degree over the last few decades, and regulations were much stronger throughout much of the history of our country.

Appalling that the situation has been allowed to develop- to the point now it is probably as dangerous to try and stop gun ownership as it is to allow it.
Send all the NRL memebers to the front lines of Afghanistan or any other current war and- see how
much fun it is.
There is another killing field in Minneapolis, today A disgruntled worker can so easily take revenge with a legal gun.
The USA like to think itself the best country in the world- the world leader- well it certainly is as far as gun deaths in the civilian population is concerned

All of the Ten Amendments of the original Bill of Rights have downsides. For example, the First Amendment lets people write or depict offensive things; the Fifth Amendment has allowed some criminals to go free and the Second Amendment allows wide ownership of firearms. Each of these have come under attack from moralizing lobbies of one kind or another, each one claiming incalculable harm.

The Second Amendment has a fascinating history that has nothing to do with any gun lobby. The existence of an individual right has now been acknowledged by the Supreme Court.

I'm not going to argue First Amendment theory. What I would like to do is to ask people to consider the consequences of its abolition: the huge, contentious, daunting, possibly dangerous horribly expensive job of snatching people's last line of personal protection from their hands, hearths and homes.

The government has already done exploratory studies in this area and all of them envision some level of resistance. Compensating voluntary surrenders would cost hundreds of millions of dollars. Most would object, many would just hide some of their guns elsewhere, and a small percentage would actively resist. Political consequences would be heavy.

Imagine sweeps based on BATF records, midnight raids, houses surrounded, kicked in doors, forced search and seizure, frightened police, mass arrests and people killed. The price of illegal guns would skyrocket and underground factories emerge.

This is morality?

President Obama deserves much credit for his Middle East policies. While maintaining its historical role as the defender of Israel, he likewise understands that the right-wing agenda of Israel's current government is the main obstacle thwarting any movement at all towards progress on attaining a peaceful settlement with their Palestinian neighbors. America pays dearly for this recalcitrance in spilled blood and fortunes wasted through war.

As a Jew who longs to see the Jewish state at peace, I totally reject Netanyahu's policies. The most powerful way to defuse the standoff with Iran is, in my opinion, for Israel to take away the Iranian rationale for their hatred of Israel by finally achieving a two state solution with the Palestinians. So very many other issues would fall by the wayside if only this issue would be given true attention.

Hatred towards America is justified world-over by our blind neglect of the Palestinian issue when in fact the truth is, Netanyahu refuses to budge on this. So, if he cannot explore peace with his neighbors, he should not expect America to explore yet another war against the Islamic world on their behalf.

Not doubt the austerity is for the poor masses , while  rich as usual live high on the hog, pay zero or bare minimum taxes. Just like what the Romney's of this world have been doing, and now  his surrogates, who like this  tax shelter / tax avoidance specialist's ideas have him as their pasty . Do their bidding, where their tax burden would be reduced to less then 2%.   It is just no only Greece and Spain, where the rich  etc pay no taxes. Italy is far worst in particular with Rome where there is the RC Vatican, a state within a state enjoying all the diplomatic privilege,  accepting none of the responsibilities and paying absolutely zero taxes. All the while the hierarchy live high on the hog , in that palace.
Netanyahu is a failed leader in need of a war to get his people to stop thinking about his failed leadership.
Israel is willing to fight Iran to the last American soldier...

It is your assumption that we are less aware of what is happening in Iran than Israel?
Our foreign policy should be dictated by Israel?
Is that why we give over $3 billion each year in handout to Israel?
the money which we certainly can use here for improving schools and working on our infrastructure.

American citizens should understand that while Netanyahu is very pushy for the US to draw red lines, the US has the same interests at stake. A nuclear Iran would be terrible for the US. We must remember that Iran is an ememy not just to Israel, but to us as well.

A coordinated campaign of sabotage is being conducted against the Iranian program by Israel, the US and some European nations. Both Netanyahu and Obama are completely aware of the status of the program. Both know it has been very successful. Obama's public patience is based on this knowledge. Behind closed doors Obama is talking about red lines and Netanyahu is talking about waiting.

Netanyahu would like to see Romney as President whom he knows Romney would be easier for him to influence. Romney is no match for Netanyahu. For that reason alone, Americans should be voting for Obama.

I do not believe for one moment  that all these comments are  purely anti- Israel but rather they are because of not wanting to be pushed by Israel into another costly war! How many more young lives does the US have to loose or want to loose? Besides, would Romney's sons want to volunteer? I DO NOT think so!

Power demands balance. Israel is the sole nuclear power in the MidEast. In this regard Israel will lose its supremacy if Iran – or any MidEast nation for that matter – goes nuclear. Israel's power is thus stalemated – balanced if you will. They don't wish this to happen any more than the U.S. did when its nuclear power position was put in check by the Soviets.

There has never been a nuclear exchange between any two nations – the U.S. and Russia, Pakistan and India etc. – because of this balance of nuclear power. In fact it is this balance of power that has led belligerent nations to the negotiating table rather than to underground bunkers.

Is Israel afraid of losing their nuclear dominance? Most assuredly. It means they might actually have to negotiate with their enemies as all other nations in their position have done for the past 70 years.

The strangest thing in this story is the suggestion that the leak from the Israeli Foreign Office suggesting that sanctions might work was the handiwork of Avigdor Liebman.   If Leibman were, say, Foreign Minister of Austria,  there would be an international uproar over his extremist  views.   Of course, there is also the suggestion in the piece that the leak could also have been master- minded by Bibi himself . The bottom line is the Israelis have been conducting a massive propaganda campaign ( can anyone believe that cartoonish image of a pre- World War 1 anarchist's bomb that  heBibi held up at the UN?).  I am surprised that Americans tolerate this attempt to interfere with their electoral process,  or even to tell the President  of the country that bankrolls their military what his moral duty is.   Mr Netanyahu should be obliged to register as a foreign agent upon entering the US.

I wish it was true. If the Government of Israel accepts our form of Democracy, we will solve the Palestinian problem. The main problem in Middle East and the Muslim world is that of Palestine. The inhumane condition of the occupation of Palestine. The abhorrent treatment of the population of West Bank and Gaza, the check points etc.
I also take issue that the Israel Government represent the Western form of democracy/culture. I wonder how many of us today would stand quietly if a massacre like Sabra and Shatilla camps were to happen in our backyard?
It was sanctioned by the State of Israel.
The day Israel accepts our form of Jeffersonian form of democracy, Palestinian issue would be solved and peace will prevail in the Holy Lands.
One person one vote and live happily

Democracy is an idea that we embrace; it is not our religious duty to spread it around the world. If other countries function under other systems without committing crimes against humanity, we should butt out of their internal affairs. Israel, being a Democracy, should not give them sole claim to our friendship.

The ironic thing is that Democracy is touted from the Republican side while they try to destroy it at home!

Wizarat -

Not true. The Jewish state of Israel set up a democratic, secular government and is one of the most ethnically diverse and progressive nations in the world. Arab citizens of israel participate fully in government; equal rights are assured for women, gay, and minorites; and freedom of the press and religion are protected.

Israel built its security wall for one reason: to protect Israeli civilians from the relentless Palestinian terrorist attacks and suicide bombers launched in 2000. Before its construction, no manmade or natural barrier kept terrorists and bombers from simply walking into Israel to detonate themselve in buses, restaurants, hotels and schools. It has saved lived Israeli fatalities from terrorism and bombers in Israel dropped by almost 100% after the fence was built.

Israel will remove the checkpoints when they are no longer needed. The checkpoints unfortunately inconvenience ordinary Palestinians, just as security checks at US airports inconvenience all travelers. But security checkpoints are there to save innocent lives. Israel set up checkpoints during the height of the Palestinian terrorist campaign, which murdered and maimed thousands of Israeli citizens. Since late 2009 Israel has been able to dramatically reduce the number of checkpoints as terrorist attempts have decreased.

Israel has had no presence in Gaza since August 2005. Gaza is governmed solely by Hamas with support of Iran.

I am amazed that so many commenters have so little grasp of what is going on in the Middle East, yet dare express their opinions.

How many democracies like ours are there in the Middle East? One! Israel. That is the reason that Israeli leaders try to work closely with the U.S. Israel, as an ally of the U.S., provides critical intelligence to our government. It is our best source of information from someone in the region with real intelligence and western know-how and skills. Israel happens to be in the Middle East geographically, but it is western in every other way. It is like a miniature United States. Supporting Israel is exactly like supporting us.

Why does Netanyahu care about Iran at all? Iran has threatened the west (because it is not Muslim) and Israel, in particular, as the easiest target of western culture.

Why should Obama care? Because Iran threatens to become a nuclear power that has terrorist sympathies and that supports terrorism. What would prevent terrorists from using Iran's nuclear capabilities - an extremist like Ahmadinajad?

Look at history. When Russia was supplying Cuba with weapons we put a long-term cessation on our dealings with Cuba. Cuba in its day (1959 to recently) was no different than Iran today. The only difference is that people do not understand how little Israel has to do with it. Israel is a propaganda pawn for Muslims, not a cause of problems.

Readers of the NY Times: read appropriate material before judging blindly.

A vote for Romney is a vote for war. He is practically guaranteeing it. And he is going to go back to waterboarding. The Obama era has been trying enough from a warfare standpoint, but can anyone really imagine going back to the neocon Bush policies? How did that work for us? And what about the Yahu with that silly bomb Illustration today. Yeah, chicken little, the sky is falling.
I for one am glad President Obama realizes he isn't running for the presidency of Israel.  This Netanyahu is an abomination.

Israel is the problem by not resolving the Palestinian issue. It is the problem for not doing what it promised us after Camp David. It is the problem that we spend over three billion dollars yearly to keep solvent. Money that we can use to fix Interstate 15 and 80 and we can provide good jobs for our own right here in this country.

Wizarat -

Not true. Israel has not stalled the peace process. Peace takes two. Israel has repeatedly offered to make far-reaching compromises, but it cannot move forward alone. Israel cannot simply announce a new border without legitimate Palestinian leaders who can implement an agreement. Israel must have assurances that Palestinians can maintain law and order, control terrorist groups like Hamas, educate their societies for peace and quit demonizing the Israelis and Jewish people through schoold textbooks and tyhe media

Over the past 75 years, Israel has repeatedly shown its willingness to make territorial compromises and accept a 2-state solution - in 1937 (before it's creation), 1947, 1979, 200, and 2008 - but Palestinian and other Arab leaders have repeatedly said no. They have rejected any Jewish state, no matter how small its territory, and tried to destroy it through wars and terrorism.

Palestinians must begin to say yes to peace and agree to compromises that will fulfill the national aspirations of both peoples.

Eugene
I wish it was true. You do know what was agreed at the Camp David accord. Just repeating the old statements that Israel has no partners in this process and continued annexation of occupied territories will never have a willing partner.
It is time to forget about the two state solution, it is just not possible anymore and it is Israel’s fault because it is the Big guy in the arena. Mitt Romney is right that there is no solution in the near future. We will have to wait till Israel annexes all of West Bank and declares Jeffersonian Democracy, same as we have here.

I see a lot of comments on here getting down on Netanyahu for pushing the U.S. into helping them fight a battle. Let us not forget Israel is not the problem here, Iran is the country making inflammatory statements about the right of Israel to exist. Why aren't the comments directed at this disturbing attitude coming from the religious rulers in Tehran.

It is very interesting to note that the leaked report from the Israeli foreign ministry states, “the international sanctions already imposed on Iran are having a deep effect on the country’s economy, according to the official, and may, according to some assessments, also be affecting the stability of the Iranian government.” Why is Mr. Netanyahu so impassioned about setting “clear red lines” with Iran?

This seems to answer the question about Netanyahu trying to influence the U.S. election. Per Andrew Sullivan from the Daily Beast News paper, “Benjamin Netanyahu’s first goal is clearly to blow up the U.S election.” Nicholas Kristof from the New York Times stated “Never before has an American politician sided with a foreign leader in a conflict with our government.” Mr. Romney and the GOP will have nothing to do with this, a war with Iran to influence the U.S election, never!

Mr. Netanyahu is a savvy politician and he has been watching the poles and he knows that he will have deal with President Obama after the November elections. He should stop beating the war drums and distance himself from Mitt Romney who stated that there will never be peace between the Palestinians and the Israelis.

It is not just putting us in Enemy category, remember in 1967 Israel has attacked our ship (S S Liberty) and killed 34 of our soldiers and wounded 175 men in international waters of the coast of Egypt

The other headline on your on-line front page says a lot:  "Netanyahu Has ‘Red Line’ for Iran, but Softer Tone for U.S."  The parallelism of that headline implies that Israel faces two foes:  Iran, toward which it takes a "hard line"; and the U.S., toward which it takes a softer line.  That may be how Mr. Netanyahu sees matters; but if so, what can Israel do when it puts its best friend in the world into the enemy category? When you have to treat your best friends as enemies, you have no friends left.
When is Israel going to join the NPT?

The American people have it in their power to make it crystal clear to Shel, Bibi, and the neocon agents of a foreign power that America will NEVER be conned into fighting another proxy war for Israel--NEVER. If, after being conned with neocon lies into sending their kids to have their faces blown off for Israel in the total disaster of Iraq, the American public is dumb enough to let itself be conned into war again, America deserves the bankruptcy and depression from $300 oil it will get.

Grover, don't omit the fact that Israel created Hezbullah and Hamas as the US created Taliban in the form of Mujahiden. Then Hezbullah as Hamas turned into resistance force. Iran is just using Hezbullah as an extension for influence. Iran itself became the victim of proxy war when Pakistani supported Taliban slaughtered their diplomats in northern Afghanistan in 1998. If Taliban were in power, the movement would have been a significant threat to Iran. For you to discount MAD concerning Iran because it would funnel dirty bombs to one of these organizations ignores the fact that these materials are traceable. Also know that Iran is trying to expand its influence not destroy itself over the use of a dirty bomb. Enough of AIPAC propaganda. Israel has to learn how to make peace and manage its issues and not try ways to draw US for yet another major destructive, fruitless war.

To Lane since when do you have such confidence that our president has never done and will never do anything to stop Iran? Just because our president isn't out-sourcing his power to Israel - is that your point?He isn't doing what Bibi wants? You need to decide which nation you support - where is your citizenship American or Israeli? I support my president - Not the prime minister of Israel!

The unpopularity in America of an economically disastrous American war against  Iran will have the potential to seriously undermine support for Israel in America. Is "protecting" Israel by fighting a new war in Iran, at the cost of hundreds of billions in new debt to China, and depression for the whole world from $300 oil, truly in AMERICA'S interest, as opposed to Likud's, especially since Pakistan can already vaporize Israel any time it wants to?
